Expectation1: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation1: The mentee has a small question about terminology that isn't blocking their work.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: A notice has been posted about an optional training session happening next week.
Story: I stood at the edge of the construction site, the hum of machinery vibrating through my boots. My mentor had always emphasized, “If you’re unsure, ask. Don’t let questions pile up.” I had a small question about a term in the safety manual—nothing urgent, but it nagged at me. I knew I should message my mentor, just to keep communication open like he expected. But as a laborer, I was also expected to pull my weight, follow protocols, and not get distracted. The foreman had just posted a notice about an optional training session next week. Some of the guys were already grumbling about how it would cut into their overtime, and I could feel the unspoken pressure to show I was a team player, not someone who needed extra help or time away from the job. My phone buzzed in my pocket, a reminder from my mentor to check in if I had any concerns. I stared at the notice, then at my phone, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in, unsure which expectation I should meet first.
